news_summary: Today's positive news highlights breakthroughs in understanding ancient predators and canine cognition, exciting entertainment releases for summer, and significant international efforts to address global challenges.
news_summary_fr: Les nouvelles positives d'aujourd'hui mettent en lumière des avancées dans la compréhension des prédateurs anciens et de la cognition canine, des sorties de divertissement passionnantes pour l'été et des efforts internationaux significatifs pour relever les défis mondiaux.
news_summary_es: Las noticias positivas de hoy destacan avances en la comprensión de los antiguos depredadores y la cognición canina, emocionantes estrenos de entretenimiento para el verano e importantes esfuerzos internacionales para hacer frente a los retos mundiales.

articles.title: ‘Stealth flippers’ helped this extinct mega-predator stalk its prey
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 16 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02277-4180-million-year-old fossil suggests Temnodontosaurus had several adaptations for quiet swimming — plus, why damage to mitochondria during waking hours might explain the need for sleep.
articles.content:
180-million-year-old fossil suggests Temnodontosaurus had several adaptations for quiet swimming — plus, why damage to mitochondria during waking hours might explain the need for sleep.

Download the Nature Podcast 16 July 2025

In this episode:

00:48 The ancient mega-predator with a ‘stealth mode’

The extinct marine mega-predator Temnodontosaurus had specialized adaptations to stealthily hunt its prey, suggests an analysis of a fossil flipper. Although Temnodontosaurus was a member of a well-studied group of marine reptiles called ichthyosaurs, its lifestyle has been a mystery due to a lack of preserved soft tissue. Now, a team have studied the fossil remains of a fore-fin, revealing several anatomical details that probably reduced low-frequency noise as the animal swam. It’s thought that these adaptations helped Temnodontosaurus stalk other ichthyosaurs and squid-like creatures that made up its prey.

Research Article: Lindgren et al.

09:46 Research Highlights

Research shows that future space probes could navigate using two stars as reference points, and how objects are more memorable when people encounter them while feeling positive emotions.

Research Highlight: Lonely spacecraft can navigate the stars

Research Highlight: Memory gets a boost from positive emotion

12:11 ‘Leaky’ mitochondria could be the root cause of sleep

Cumulative damage to mitochondria during waking hours could be a key driver for the need to sleep, according to new research. In fruit-fly experiments, a team showed that being awake caused damage to mitochondria found in a specific set of neurons. Once this damage reaches a threshold it kicks off a process that ultimately leads to sleep. Although it’s unclear if this process occurs in humans, the researchers think this need for sleep may be an ancient process that coincided with the evolution of organisms with power-hungry nervous systems.

Research Article: Sarnataro et al.

23:04 The secret messages used to trick peer-review AI

Researchers have been sneaking text into their papers designed to trick AI tools into giving them a positive peer-review report. Multiple instances of these prompts have been found, which are typically hidden using white text or an extremely small font invisible to humans. We discuss the rise in this practice and what is being done to tackle it.

Nature: Scientists hide messages in papers to game AI peer review

Video: Could hidden AI prompts game peer review?

Subscribe to Nature Briefing, an unmissable daily round-up of science news, opinion and analysis free in your inbox every weekday.

Never miss an episode. Subscribe to the Nature Podcast on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, YouTube Music or your favourite podcast app. An RSS feed for the Nature Podcast is available too.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights scientific discoveries about an extinct marine predator's adaptations and new insights into the biological need for sleep, which represent valuable scientific breakthroughs and deepen our understanding of natural history and biology. These findings inspire curiosity and hope about ongoing scientific progress.
articles.personality_title: Ancient mega-predator used stealthy flippers to hunt quietly
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
About 180 million years ago, a giant marine predator called Temnodontosaurus roamed the oceans. This creature was part of the ichthyosaurs family, known for being powerful swimmers. Scientists have long wondered how such a large predator could sneak up on its prey.

**What happened**
Researchers studied a well-preserved flipper fossil of Temnodontosaurus and discovered it had special features that helped it swim quietly. These “stealth flippers” reduced water noise, allowing the predator to approach prey without being detected. The study also offered fresh ideas on why animals need sleep, linking it to protecting cell parts called mitochondria from damage during waking hours.

**Impact**
This discovery sheds light on how ancient creatures adapted to their environments in clever ways. Understanding Temnodontosaurus’s silent hunting style helps us appreciate the complexity of life millions of years ago. Plus, connecting sleep to cellular repair opens new doors in biology and health research.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to explore more fossils to see if other prehistoric marine animals had similar stealth features. They also want to study how sleep protects cells, which could lead to better treatments for sleep-related health problems.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A 180-million-year-old fossil reveals how a giant sea predator used quiet flippers to hunt, deepening our knowledge of ancient life and why sleep matters.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un méga-prédateur ancien utilisait des nageoires furtives pour chasser silencieusement
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Il y a environ 180 millions d’années, un grand prédateur marin appelé Temnodontosaurus parcourait les océans. Cet animal faisait partie de la famille des ictyosaures, connus pour leurs capacités de nageurs puissants. Les scientifiques se demandaient comment un si grand prédateur pouvait approcher discrètement ses proies.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs ont étudié un fossile bien conservé de la nageoire du Temnodontosaurus et ont découvert qu’elle possédait des caractéristiques spéciales pour nager silencieusement. Ces « nageoires furtives » réduisaient le bruit dans l’eau, permettant au prédateur de surprendre ses proies sans être détecté. L’étude a aussi proposé de nouvelles idées sur le besoin de sommeil, en le reliant à la protection des mitochondries, des parties des cellules, contre les dégâts pendant les heures d’éveil.

**Impact**
Cette découverte éclaire la manière dont les créatures anciennes s’adaptaient intelligemment à leur environnement. Comprendre le mode de chasse silencieux du Temnodontosaurus nous fait mieux apprécier la complexité de la vie il y a des millions d’années. En plus, le lien entre sommeil et réparation cellulaire ouvre de nouvelles perspectives en biologie et en santé.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques veulent examiner plus de fossiles pour voir si d’autres animaux marins préhistoriques avaient des caractéristiques furtives similaires. Ils souhaitent aussi étudier comment le sommeil protège les cellules, ce qui pourrait améliorer les traitements des troubles du sommeil.

**En une phrase**
Un fossile vieux de 180 millions d’années montre comment un grand prédateur marin utilisait des nageoires silencieuses pour chasser, enrichissant notre compréhension de la vie ancienne et de l’importance du sommeil.
articles.personality_title_es: Un mega depredador antiguo usaba aletas sigilosas para cazar en silencio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Hace unos 180 millones de años, un gran depredador marino llamado Temnodontosaurus recorría los océanos. Este animal pertenecía a la familia de los ictiosaurios, conocidos por ser nadadores poderosos. Los científicos se preguntaban cómo un depredador tan grande podía acercarse sigilosamente a sus presas.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores estudiaron un fósil bien conservado de la aleta de Temnodontosaurus y descubrieron que tenía características especiales para nadar en silencio. Estas “aletas sigilosas” reducían el ruido en el agua, permitiendo que el depredador se acercara sin ser detectado. El estudio también propuso nuevas ideas sobre por qué los animales necesitan dormir, relacionándolo con la protección de las mitocondrias, partes de las células, contra daños durante las horas de vigilia.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo muestra cómo las criaturas antiguas se adaptaban de formas inteligentes a su entorno. Entender el estilo de caza silenciosa del Temnodontosaurus nos ayuda a apreciar la complejidad de la vida hace millones de años. Además, la conexión entre el sueño y la reparación celular abre nuevas puertas en la biología y la salud.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean estudiar más fósiles para ver si otros animales marinos prehistóricos tenían características sigilosas similares. También quieren investigar cómo el sueño protege las células, lo que podría mejorar tratamientos para problemas relacionados con el sueño.

**Una frase clave**
Un fósil de 180 millones de años revela cómo un gran depredador marino usaba aletas silenciosas para cazar, profundizando nuestro conocimiento sobre la vida antigua y la importancia del sueño.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-colored painting of a sleek, large ichthyosaur-like marine reptile gliding silently through calm, deep ocean waters, its fore-flippers softly illuminated and subtly stylized to resemble smooth, streamlined fins designed for stealth; nearby, ghostly, semi-transparent silhouettes of squid-like creatures and smaller marine reptiles fade gently into the background, emphasizing the predator’s quiet, skillful stalking in an ancient underwater world.

articles.title: Summer's must-watch TV & film: 'Jaws at 50', Acapulco's final season and 'Wednesday' returns
articles.summary: Our TV critic Dheepthika Laurent joins Eve Jackson to unpack the highlights of July and August's biggest series and films – from "Jaws at 50" featuring exclusive interviews, to the light-hearted drama of "Acapulco", the Emmy buzz surrounding this year's nominations and the exciting new "Black Panther" spinoff "Eyes of Wakanda" on Disney+. Don't miss our full rundown and exclusive insights into what to watch this summer!
articles.content:
Summer's must-watch TV & film: 'Jaws at 50', Acapulco's final season and 'Wednesday' returns

Culture

To display this content from YouTube, you must enable advertisement tracking and audience measurement. Accept Manage my choices One of your browser extensions seems to be blocking the video player from loading. To watch this content, you may need to disable it on this site. Try again arts24 © FRANCE 24 11:19

11:19 min

Play (11:21 min)

From the show

Our TV critic Dheepthika Laurent joins Eve Jackson to unpack the highlights of July and August's biggest series and films – from "Jaws at 50" featuring exclusive interviews, to the light-hearted drama of "Acapulco", the Emmy buzz surrounding this year's nominations and the exciting new "Black Panther" spinoff "Eyes of Wakanda" on Disney+. Don't miss our full rundown and exclusive insights into what to watch this summer!
articles.source: News and stories on CULTURE, movies, music, literature - France 24
articles.reasoning: The article highlights positive cultural content and entertainment options for the summer, including nostalgic retrospectives, popular series returning, and new exciting spinoffs. It promotes enjoyment, relaxation, and cultural engagement, which can uplift and entertain a wide audience.
articles.personality_title: Summer TV and film highlights: classics, finales, and new favorites
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Summer is here, and with it comes a fresh lineup of exciting TV shows and films to enjoy. From nostalgic documentaries to popular series and brand-new stories, there's something for everyone to relax and have fun.

**What happened**
This summer, viewers can dive into 'Jaws at 50,' a special look back at the iconic shark movie with exclusive interviews that bring the story to life. Fans of light-hearted drama can catch the final season of 'Acapulco,' which wraps up its fun and heartfelt story. Plus, the spooky and clever series 'Wednesday' is back for more adventures, while Disney+ is launching 'Eyes of Wakanda,' a thrilling new spin-off from the 'Black Panther' universe.

**Impact**
These shows and films offer more than just entertainment—they bring people together, spark conversations, and brighten up the summer days. Whether you’re into classic films, heartfelt stories, or exciting new worlds, this lineup encourages cultural enjoyment and a chance to unwind.

**What's next step**
Viewers can look forward to tuning in over the coming weeks and months to catch these releases. Keeping an eye on Emmy nominations also adds extra excitement, as some of these shows are getting recognized for their quality. Planning some watch parties or solo binge time could be a great way to enjoy the season.

**One-sentence takeaway**
This summer’s TV and film lineup mixes nostalgia, fresh stories, and fan favorites to keep everyone entertained and inspired.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les incontournables TV et films de l'été : classiques, saisons finales et nouvelles séries
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
L'été est là, accompagné d'une nouvelle sélection passionnante de séries et de films à découvrir. Des documentaires nostalgiques aux séries populaires en passant par de nouvelles histoires, il y en a pour tous les goûts pour se détendre et s'amuser.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Cet été, les spectateurs peuvent plonger dans « Jaws at 50 », un regard spécial sur le célèbre film « Les Dents de la mer » avec des interviews exclusives qui donnent vie à l'histoire. Les fans de drames légers peuvent suivre la dernière saison d'« Acapulco », qui conclut son récit amusant et touchant. De plus, la série « Wednesday » revient pour de nouvelles aventures, tandis que Disney+ lance « Eyes of Wakanda », un nouveau spin-off passionnant de l'univers « Black Panther ».

**Impact**
Ces séries et films offrent plus que du simple divertissement : ils rassemblent les gens, suscitent des discussions et illuminent les journées d'été. Que vous aimiez les films classiques, les histoires touchantes ou les nouveaux univers, cette sélection encourage la culture et la détente.

**Prochaine étape**
Les téléspectateurs peuvent attendre avec impatience de suivre ces sorties dans les semaines et mois à venir. Suivre les nominations aux Emmy Awards ajoute aussi une touche d'excitation, car certaines séries sont reconnues pour leur qualité. Organiser des soirées visionnage ou des sessions en solo peut être une excellente façon de profiter de la saison.

**Phrase-clé**
La programmation TV et cinéma de cet été mêle nostalgie, nouveautés et favoris du public pour divertir et inspirer tout le monde.
articles.personality_title_es: Lo mejor de la TV y el cine de verano: clásicos, finales y nuevas favoritas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El verano ya está aquí, trayendo una nueva lista emocionante de series y películas para disfrutar. Desde documentales nostálgicos hasta series populares y nuevas historias, hay algo para todos para relajarse y divertirse.

**Qué pasó**
Este verano, los espectadores pueden sumergirse en 'Jaws at 50', una mirada especial al icónico filme del tiburón con entrevistas exclusivas que dan vida a la historia. Los fans del drama ligero pueden ver la temporada final de 'Acapulco', que cierra su historia divertida y emotiva. Además, la serie 'Wednesday' regresa con más aventuras, mientras Disney+ lanza 'Eyes of Wakanda', un emocionante nuevo spin-off del universo de 'Black Panther'.

**Impacto**
Estas series y películas ofrecen más que entretenimiento: reúnen a las personas, generan conversaciones y alegran los días de verano. Ya sea que te gusten los clásicos, las historias conmovedoras o nuevos mundos, esta selección fomenta el disfrute cultural y la relajación.

**Próximo paso**
Los espectadores pueden esperar sintonizar en las próximas semanas y meses para ver estos lanzamientos. Seguir las nominaciones a los Emmy también añade emoción, ya que algunas de estas series están siendo reconocidas por su calidad. Planear fiestas para verlas o maratones en solitario puede ser una gran forma de disfrutar la temporada.

**Frase clave**
La programación de TV y cine de este verano mezcla nostalgia, historias nuevas y favoritas para mantener a todos entretenidos e inspirados.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting showing a vintage shark fin cutting through calm ocean waves beside a classic film camera on a sandy beach, with a festive Mexican seaside village backdrop featuring colorful decorations and a silhouetted black panther subtly watching from nearby jungle foliage.

articles.title: EU agrees 'unprecedented' round of sanctions targeting Russia's oil exports
articles.summary: The European Union on Friday reached an agreement on an 18th sanctions package against Russia over its war in Ukraine, with a raft of measures aimed at dealing further blows to Russia's oil and energy industry. France's top diplomat described the measures as "unprecedented".
articles.content:
The European Union and Britain on Friday sought to ramp up economic pressure on Russia to halt the war in Ukraine by slashing a price cap meant to choke off revenues from key oil exports.

The move from the EU was part of a sweeping new package of sanctions – the bloc's 18th since the start of Russia's 2022 invasion – that also took aim at Moscow's banking sector and military capabilities.

The measures come as allies closely watch whether US President Donald Trump follows through on his threat to punish Moscow over Russian President Vladimir Putin's failure to move forward on a truce.

"The message is clear: Europe will not back down in its support for Ukraine. The EU will keep raising the pressure until Russia ends its war," said EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas.

British foreign minister David Lammy announced the UK was joining the EU price cap sanction, saying they were "striking at the heart of the Russian energy sector".

"As Putin continues to stall on serious peace talks, we will not stand by," he said.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky hailed the EU's new sanctions as "essential and timely".

The bloc's new measures were approved after Slovakia dropped a weeks-long block following talks with Brussels over separate plans to phase out Russian gas imports.

Kremlin-friendly Slovakian leader Robert Fico – whose country remains dependent on Russian energy – dropped his opposition after getting what he called "guarantees" from Brussels over future gas prices.

To display this content from X (Twitter), you must enable advertisement tracking and audience measurement. Accept Manage my choices

France's Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot called the latest EU moves "unprecedented" and said that "together with the United States we will force Vladimir Putin into a ceasefire".

But the Kremlin said it would seek to "minimise" the impact, and warned the measures would backfire.

The price cap is originally a G7 initiative aimed at limiting the amount of money Russia makes by exporting oil to countries such as China and India.

The EU and Britain said they would lower the cap on Russian oil exported to third countries around the world to 15 percent below market value.

That comes despite Washington's allies failing to convince Trump to go along with the plan.

Set at $60 a barrel by the G7 in 2022, the measure bans shipping firms and insurance companies dealing with Russia from exporting oil above the cap amount.

Under the new plan – which Brussels hopes other G7 allies like Canada and Japan will join – the initial level will start at $47.60 and can be adjusted as oil prices change in the future.

The EU already largely cut off imports of Russian oil.

EU officials admit the scheme will not be as effective without US involvement.

Tankers, refinery, banks

In addition to the oil price cap, officials said the EU was blacklisting over 100 more vessels in the "shadow fleet" of ageing tankers that security analysts say Russia uses to circumvent oil export curbs.

It was also imposing measures to stop the defunct Baltic Sea gas pipelines Nord Stream 1 and 2 from being brought back online in the future.

Read moreArms deliveries, sanctions loopholes: How Trump's recent moves benefit Russia

Among other targets, sanctions will be placed on a Russian-owned oil refinery in India and two Chinese banks, as the EU seeks to curb Moscow's ties with international partners.

The bloc is expanding a transaction ban on dealings with Russian banks and placing more restrictions on the export of "dual-use" goods that Russia's forces could use on the battlefield in Ukraine.

The latest round of measures comes after Trump on Monday threatened to hit buyers of Russian energy with massive "secondary tariffs" if Moscow doesn't halt the fighting in 50 days.

The move from Trump represented a dramatic pivot from his previous effort of rapprochement with the Kremlin, as he said his patience was running out with Putin.

The multiple rounds of international sanctions imposed on Moscow in the three-and-a-half years since its invasion have failed so far to cripple the Russian economy or slow its war effort.

But Western officials argue that despite Russia's economy largely weathering the punishment so far, key economic indicators such as interest rates and inflation are getting worse.

(FRANCE 24 with AFP)
articles.source: Business news, technology, media and finance reports - France 24
articles.reasoning: The news describes a significant international effort to pressure Russia economically to end its war in Ukraine, which aligns with promoting peace and justice. While it involves political conflict and sanctions, the intent is to stop violence and support Ukraine, which can be seen as hopeful and positive by many.
articles.personality_title: EU takes bold new step to limit Russia’s oil profits
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The European Union has been working for months to pressure Russia to stop its war in Ukraine. One key tool has been sanctions—economic penalties designed to make it harder for Russia to fund its military actions. This latest move is the EU’s 18th set of sanctions since the war began in 2022.

**What happened**
On Friday, the EU agreed to lower the maximum price allowed for Russian oil exports. This price cap aims to reduce the money Russia earns from selling oil, which is a major source of income. Alongside this, the EU introduced new sanctions targeting Russia’s banks and military sectors to further restrict resources that support the war.

**Impact**
By cutting the price Russia can charge for its oil, the EU hopes to squeeze Russia’s war budget without causing too much disruption to global energy supplies. These “unprecedented” measures put strong economic pressure on Russia, pushing for a peaceful end to the conflict in Ukraine.

**What’s next step**
The EU and its allies will continue monitoring the effects of these sanctions and adjust as needed. They also watch closely how other world leaders, like the U.S. President, respond and cooperate, aiming for a united front to encourage peace.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The EU’s new price cap on Russian oil is a powerful move to limit war funding and support hope for peace in Ukraine.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE franchit une étape audacieuse pour limiter les profits pétroliers de la Russie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
L’Union européenne travaille depuis des mois à faire pression sur la Russie pour qu’elle cesse sa guerre en Ukraine. Un outil clé a été les sanctions—des mesures économiques visant à compliquer le financement des actions militaires russes. Ce dernier mouvement est le 18e paquet de sanctions de l’UE depuis le début de la guerre en 2022.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Vendredi, l’UE a accepté d’abaisser le prix maximum autorisé pour les exportations de pétrole russe. Ce plafond vise à réduire l’argent que la Russie gagne en vendant son pétrole, une source majeure de revenus. En plus, l’UE a imposé de nouvelles sanctions ciblant les banques et secteurs militaires russes pour restreindre davantage les ressources de guerre.

**Impact**
En coupant le prix que la Russie peut demander pour son pétrole, l’UE espère réduire le budget de guerre russe sans trop perturber l’approvisionnement mondial en énergie. Ces mesures « sans précédent » exercent une forte pression économique, encourageant une fin pacifique du conflit en Ukraine.

**Prochaine étape**
L’UE et ses alliés continueront de suivre les effets de ces sanctions et les adapteront si nécessaire. Ils surveillent également la réaction d’autres dirigeants mondiaux, comme le président américain, pour favoriser une coopération unie en faveur de la paix.

**Message clé**
Le nouveau plafond de prix de l’UE sur le pétrole russe est une mesure forte pour limiter le financement de la guerre et soutenir l’espoir de paix en Ukraine.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE da un paso audaz para limitar las ganancias del petróleo ruso
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La Unión Europea ha estado trabajando durante meses para presionar a Rusia a detener su guerra en Ucrania. Una herramienta clave han sido las sanciones, castigos económicos diseñados para dificultar que Rusia financie sus acciones militares. Esta última medida es el 18º paquete de sanciones de la UE desde que comenzó la guerra en 2022.

**Qué pasó**
El viernes, la UE acordó reducir el precio máximo permitido para las exportaciones de petróleo ruso. Este límite busca disminuir el dinero que Rusia gana vendiendo petróleo, una fuente principal de ingresos. Además, la UE introdujo nuevas sanciones contra bancos y sectores militares rusos para restringir más recursos que apoyan la guerra.

**Impacto**
Al bajar el precio que Rusia puede cobrar por su petróleo, la UE espera reducir el presupuesto de guerra ruso sin causar gran impacto en el suministro global de energía. Estas medidas “sin precedentes” ejercen una fuerte presión económica para promover una solución pacífica al conflicto en Ucrania.

**Próximo paso**
La UE y sus aliados seguirán monitoreando los efectos de estas sanciones y las ajustarán según sea necesario. También observan de cerca cómo responden otros líderes mundiales, como el presidente de EE. UU., buscando una postura unida para fomentar la paz.

**Mensaje principal**
El nuevo tope de precio de la UE al petróleo ruso es un paso fuerte para limitar el financiamiento de la guerra y apoyar la esperanza de paz en Ucrania.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of a large, sturdy oil tanker chained and anchored firmly in calm blue waters, surrounded by a circle of diverse flags symbolizing the European Union and Britain, with stylized silhouettes of broken pipelines and shadowy, aging ships in the background; the scene uses warm, natural tones to convey determined unity and peaceful resolution without any human figures.

articles.title: Do dogs know who’s kind? Scientists put it to the test—and got a surprise
articles.summary: Despite our strong belief in dogs' ability to sense good from bad in people, new research shows they may not actually judge human character, at least not in the way we think. When dogs watched how humans treated other dogs, they didn’t favor the kinder person later. Even direct interactions didn’t sway their behavior. The study suggests dogs' reputational judgments might be more nuanced—or harder to study—than we realized.
articles.content:
Kyoto, Japan -- Many people tend to trust dogs' instincts regarding humans. If dogs gravitate towards you, dog lovers will likely see you as safe and trustworthy, but if dogs are apprehensive around you, some may begin to question your character. Yet how and even if dogs socially evaluate people remains a mystery.

Studies have demonstrated that cognitively complex and social animal species -- such as chimpanzees -- can form reputations of humans either through direct interaction or by observing third-party interactions. The historically intimate relationship dogs have with humans has also made them the focus of considerable research, but findings have proven inconsistent.

Previous research conducted at the Wolf Science Center in Austria found that pack-living dogs and wolves did not form reputations of individual humans after both direct and indirect experience with them. This nonjudgmental attitude may be due to the animals' limited experience interacting with humans, so further study required the participation of more experienced dogs.

In a new study, a research team observed 40 pet dog participants to investigate whether age and development influences how they form reputations of humans. They first arranged for the dogs to eavesdrop on another dog's interactions with two humans, one of whom was generous and fed the dog demonstrator, while the other did not feed the dog.

After observing another dog's experience, the dogs interacted with the two humans directly while the researchers analyzed their behavior, taking note of who the dogs approached first, along with behaviors like jumping up and their proximity to each person.

The results revealed that dogs across all age groups did not significantly prefer the generous person who fed the dog compared to the selfish person who refused to feed the dog. Their behavior toward the two humans did not exceed chance levels following indirect eavesdropping or direct experience with them.

"It's clear that reputation formation may be more complex than previously thought, even for animals like dogs that closely cooperate with humans," says corresponding researcher Hoi-Lam Jim, who recently joined the faculty at Kyoto University.

This study highlights the methodological challenges in accurately capturing dogs’ understanding and evaluation of humans. Since direct reputation formation is a prerequisite for eavesdropping, the researchers were not surprised to find no evidence of reputation formation, but they did not expect the lack of evidence for it after direct interaction.

"It is possible that methodological challenges in the experimental design, particularly the use of a two-choice test, may explain our negative findings, rather than an absence of capacity," says Jim.

To better understand what influences dogs’ sociocognitive abilities, the research team says future research should systematically compare dogs of all ages from different populations and life experiences, expanding to include free-ranging dogs, service dogs, and police dogs.

To many of us, it seems reasonable to believe that dogs socially evaluate people, but for now we simply do not know.

###

The paper "Do dogs form reputations of humans? No effect of age after indirect and direct experience in a food-giving situation" appeared on 28 June 2025 in Animal Cognition, with doi: 10.1007/s10071-025-01967-w

About Kyoto University

Kyoto University is one of Japan and Asia's premier research institutions, founded in 1897 and responsible for producing numerous Nobel laureates and winners of other prestigious international prizes. A broad curriculum across the arts and sciences at undergraduate and graduate levels complements several research centers, facilities, and offices around Japan and the world. For more information, please see: http://www.kyoto-u.ac.jp/en
articles.reasoning: The article presents new scientific research that challenges common assumptions about dogs' social cognition, highlighting the complexity of animal behavior and encouraging further study. While it does not report a breakthrough or a clear positive finding, it contributes to scientific understanding and opens avenues for future research, which is a positive development.
articles.personality_title: New research reveals dogs may not judge people’s kindness as we thought
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Many dog lovers believe dogs can sense who is kind or not in people, often trusting dogs’ behavior as a clue to human character. While some animals like chimpanzees are known to judge others by watching interactions, it was unclear if dogs do the same.

**What happened**
Scientists in Kyoto tested whether dogs prefer people who act kindly toward other dogs. They watched dogs observe how humans treated other dogs and then saw if the observing dogs chose the kinder person later. Surprisingly, the dogs did not show a clear preference for the kind person, even when they interacted directly.

**Impact**
This study challenges the popular idea that dogs easily judge human kindness. Instead, it suggests dogs’ social understanding of people might be more complicated or different than we assumed. This opens new questions for scientists about how dogs see and interpret human behavior.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to explore more detailed ways dogs might evaluate people, perhaps looking at other signals or contexts. The goal is to better understand dogs' social thinking and how they form opinions about humans in daily life.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Dogs may not simply judge human kindness by watching, but their social smarts are still a fascinating puzzle worth exploring.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle recherche montre que les chiens ne jugent pas la gentillesse comme on le pense
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Beaucoup de propriétaires de chiens pensent que leurs compagnons peuvent sentir qui est gentil ou non chez les humains, en se fiant souvent au comportement du chien pour juger le caractère d’une personne. Si certains animaux comme les chimpanzés savent évaluer les autres en observant, on ne savait pas si c’était le cas pour les chiens.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des scientifiques à Kyoto ont testé si les chiens préfèrent les personnes qui sont gentilles avec d’autres chiens. Ils ont observé comment les chiens regardaient des humains traiter d’autres chiens, puis ont vu si les chiens préféraient ensuite la personne gentille. Surprise : les chiens n’ont pas montré de préférence claire, même avec un contact direct.

**Impact**
Cette étude remet en question l’idée populaire que les chiens jugent facilement la gentillesse humaine. Elle suggère que la compréhension sociale des chiens est plus complexe ou différente de ce qu’on croyait, ce qui ouvre de nouvelles pistes pour la recherche.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs veulent explorer d’autres façons plus subtiles dont les chiens pourraient évaluer les humains, en étudiant d’autres signaux ou situations. L’objectif est de mieux comprendre la pensée sociale des chiens et comment ils forment leurs opinions.

**À retenir en une phrase**
Les chiens ne jugent pas simplement la gentillesse humaine en regardant, mais leur intelligence sociale reste un mystère captivant à explorer.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva investigación muestra que los perros no juzgan la bondad humana como pensábamos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Muchos amantes de los perros creen que sus mascotas pueden sentir quién es amable o no en las personas, confiando en el comportamiento del perro para juzgar el carácter humano. Mientras que algunos animales como los chimpancés sí evalúan a otros observando, no estaba claro si los perros hacen lo mismo.

**Qué pasó**
Científicos en Kioto probaron si los perros prefieren a personas que tratan bien a otros perros. Observaron a perros que veían cómo humanos trataban a otros perros y luego vieron si preferían a la persona amable. Sorprendentemente, los perros no mostraron preferencia clara, ni siquiera con interacción directa.

**Impacto**
Este estudio desafía la idea popular de que los perros juzgan fácilmente la bondad humana. Sugiere que la comprensión social de los perros es más compleja o diferente de lo que pensábamos, abriendo nuevas preguntas para la ciencia.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean explorar formas más detalladas en que los perros podrían evaluar a las personas, quizás analizando otras señales o contextos. El objetivo es entender mejor el pensamiento social de los perros y cómo forman opiniones sobre humanos.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Los perros pueden no juzgar la bondad humana solo con observar, pero su inteligencia social sigue siendo un misterio fascinante para explorar.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a gentle, attentive dog sitting calmly between two human silhouettes represented by softly glowing, abstract hand shapes—one offering a small bowl of food and the other empty—set against a simple, natural-toned background symbolizing subtle social evaluation and the mystery of canine trust.
